articles.headline: Don’t Call. Don’t Write. Let Me Be.
articles.snippet: How to get your name off lists, so sales people won’t call, junk mail won’t come, and spam won’t clog the in-box.
articles.abstract: How to get your name off lists, so sales people won’t call, junk mail won’t come, and spam won’t clog the in-box.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fears of the direct marketing industry came true. Once a do-not-call list was created, people did register, in droves.

articles.headline: Senate Measure Puts Spotlight on Fund-Raising
articles.snippet: The measure would require lobbyists to disclose money they raise from clients and deliver as sheaves of checks.
articles.abstract: The measure would require lobbyists to disclose money they raise from clients and deliver as sheaves of checks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 — Of all the new rules passed in Congress’s recent ethics overhauls, the most sweeping is a barely debated provision in a Senate bill passed Thursday night that could alter one of the most time-honored campaign fund-raising practices in Washington.

articles.headline: Draft Law Keeps Central Control Over Oil in Iraq
articles.snippet: The law would distribute all oil revenues through the federal government and grant Baghdad wide powers.
articles.abstract: The law would distribute all oil revenues through the federal government and grant Baghdad wide powers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Jan. 19 — After months of tense bargaining, a cabinet-level committee has produced a draft law governing Iraq’s vast oil fields that would distribute all revenues through the federal government and grant Baghdad wide powers in exploration, development and awarding major international contracts.

articles.headline: Trade Deficit Stubbornly Defies the Dollar’s Slide
articles.snippet: Although the dollar has lost a lot of ground, the nation’s trade imbalance with the world has continued to rise.
articles.abstract: Although the dollar has lost a lot of ground, the nation’s trade imbalance with the world has continued to rise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jessica Heyman’s breakfast in Paris last month was nothing out of the ordinary: a modest repast of eggs, coffee and a side salad with her husband, Jonathan Podwil, at the popular Café de Flore. But the bill was memorable — 46 euros, or about $60, at the current exchange rate. Five years ago, when the dollar was strong, the same bill would have amounted to $42.
articles.byline: By Eduardo Porter and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Madison Avenue Calling
articles.snippet: Cellphone subscribers could start to lower their bills by watching advertising on their mobile phones.
articles.abstract: Cellphone subscribers could start to lower their bills by watching advertising on their mobile phones.
articles.lead_paragraph: People often say they do not like advertisements, but that may change if the ads start lowering their cellphone bills.

articles.headline: Patent Trial Near, Bristol-Myers Counts on Resilience
articles.snippet: The trial over the patent for the drug Plavix will be critical for Bristol-Myers, which derives nearly a third of its revenue from it.
articles.abstract: The trial over the patent for the drug Plavix will be critical for Bristol-Myers, which derives nearly a third of its revenue from it.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Jan. 19 — Bristol-Myers Squibb staggered, but the drug maker has remained on its feet.

articles.headline: States Study Marketing of Lilly Pill
articles.snippet: State prosecutors have demanded Eli Lilly turn over information about the way it promoted the drug Zyprexa.
articles.abstract: State prosecutors have demanded Eli Lilly turn over information about the way it promoted the drug Zyprexa.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stepping up government investigations into Eli Lilly’s marketing of its best-selling drug Zyprexa, state prosecutors in Illinois and Vermont have demanded that the company turn over information about the way it promoted the medication.

articles.headline: I Want My Howard Stern and Oprah
articles.snippet: When it comes to new and emerging technologies like satellite radio, what exactly constitutes competition?
articles.abstract: When it comes to new and emerging technologies like satellite radio, what exactly constitutes competition?
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, I was in the middle of a long phone conversation with Craig Moffett, the Wall Street analyst who follows broadcasting for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. His purview includes the country’s two satellite radio companies, XM and Sirius. Although Mr. Moffett is more positive on XM than Sirius, he sounded a little sheepish when I asked him whether he was bullish on the sector.

articles.headline: Refugees Find Hostility and Hope on Soccer Field
articles.snippet: A boys soccer team for refugees with miserable pasts brings out the best and worst in Americans.
articles.abstract: A boys soccer team for refugees with miserable pasts brings out the best and worst in Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLARKSTON, Ga., Jan. 20 — Early last summer the mayor of this small town east of Atlanta issued a decree: no more soccer in the town park.

articles.headline: Once Given Up for Dead, Comcast Defies Its Obits
articles.snippet: The entire cable business, and Comcast, the country’s largest cable company, are sitting pretty.
articles.abstract: The entire cable business, and Comcast, the country’s largest cable company, are sitting pretty.
articles.lead_paragraph: THREE years ago, with the cable television industry in the doldrums, the Comcast Corporation’s chairman, Brian L. Roberts, approached Mel Karmazin, then the president of Viacom, with a modest proposal: give Comcast the right to show programming from such Viacom properties as CBS and MTV on the cable company’s channels so it could have a leg up on its rivals.

articles.headline: At Border, Signs of Pakistani Role in Taliban Surge
articles.snippet: Along the Afghan frontier, there are signs that Pakistani authorities have been encouraging a restoration of the Taliban.
articles.abstract: Along the Afghan frontier, there are signs that Pakistani authorities have been encouraging a restoration of the Taliban.
articles.lead_paragraph: QUETTA, Pakistan — The most explosive question about the Taliban resurgence here along the border between Afghanistan and Pakistan is this: Have Pakistani intelligence agencies been promoting the Islamic insurgency?

articles.headline: New Orleans of Future May Stay Half Its Old Size
articles.snippet: Some economists and demographers wonder whether New Orleans will top out at about half its prestorm population.
articles.abstract: Some economists and demographers wonder whether New Orleans will top out at about half its prestorm population.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 20  The empty streets, deserted avenues and abandoned houses prompt a gnawing question, nearly 17 months after Hurricane Katrina: Is this what New Orleans has come to  a city half its old size?

articles.headline: Clinton Enters ’08 Field, Fueling Race for Money
articles.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s official entrance into the 2008 presidential race highlighted the urgent need to line up supporters.
articles.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s official entrance into the 2008 presidential race highlighted the urgent need to line up supporters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton jumped into the 2008 presidential race yesterday, immediately squaring off against Senator Barack Obama and the rest of the Democratic field in what is effectively the party’s first primary, the competition for campaign donations.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Helicopter Crash Claims 13 on Deadly Day for U.S. in Iraq
articles.snippet: Seven other U.S.  soldiers were killed in separate incidents on one of the deadliest days of the war.
articles.abstract: Seven other U.S.  soldiers were killed in separate incidents on one of the deadliest days of the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Jan. 20  On one of the deadliest days for United States forces since the Iraq war began, an American helicopter crashed in a Sunni area north of Baghdad on Saturday, killing all 13 people onboard, the United States military said.

articles.headline: Big Game? An Enron Survivor Hunts for Riches
articles.snippet: The search for gas and oil has reignited to transform companies like InterOil, a leftover sliver of Enron, into Wall Street darlings.
articles.abstract: The search for gas and oil has reignited to transform companies like InterOil, a leftover sliver of Enron, into Wall Street darlings.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE South Pacific islands of Papua New Guinea, where canned mackerel occasionally serves as currency and cannibalism was once on the menu, are a long way from the corporate jungles where Enron was born.

articles.headline: Roadblocks to Greater Say on Pay
articles.snippet: Greater detail on executive pay will arrive this spring. But shareholders won’t have a greater say on how that pay is computed if some companies get their way.
articles.abstract: Greater detail on executive pay will arrive this spring. But shareholders won’t have a greater say on how that pay is computed if some companies get their way.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREATER detail on executive pay will arrive this spring, thanks to new regulatory requirements. But shareholders won’t have a greater say on how that pay is computed if companies like AT&T and Verizon Communications get their way.

articles.headline: Unabomber Wages Legal Battle to Halt the Sale of Papers
articles.snippet: Theodore J. Kaczynski is fighting to reclaim more than 40,000 pages of his writings so he can preserve them for the public to read.
articles.abstract: Theodore J. Kaczynski is fighting to reclaim more than 40,000 pages of his writings so he can preserve them for the public to read.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nine years after he began serving a life sentence for the Unabomber crimes, Theodore J. Kaczynski is fighting to reclaim more than 40,000 pages of his writings and correspondence so he can preserve them in their rawest form for the public to read.

articles.headline: M dot Strange Finds a Way at Sundance
articles.snippet: M dot Strange’s success on the Web has proved that if you produce something the consumer wants, a business model might follow.
articles.abstract: M dot Strange’s success on the Web has proved that if you produce something the consumer wants, a business model might follow.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — In the daunting hierarchy of the Sundance Film Festival, with its hype machine, big stars and indie royalty, a young movie maker named M dot Strange would seem to have little chance of gaining much attention.

articles.headline: Showdown Looms in Congress Over Drug Advertising on TV
articles.snippet: Drug advertising will face hard scrutiny in the new Congress as it considers the renewal of fees that manufacturers pay to speed reviews of new drugs.
articles.abstract: Drug advertising will face hard scrutiny in the new Congress as it considers the renewal of fees that manufacturers pay to speed reviews of new drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Drug advertising aimed at consumers, a fast-growing category that reached $4.5 billion last year, will face hard scrutiny in the new Congress, according to industry critics in both the House and Senate.

articles.headline: In Live Bacteria, Food Makers See a Bonanza
articles.snippet: More food makers are scrambling to offer products with special live microbes that boast health benefits.
articles.abstract: More food makers are scrambling to offer products with special live microbes that boast health benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fastest way to consumers’ hearts may be through their troubled stomachs.

articles.headline: Rush of Entries Gives ’08 Race Early Intensity
articles.snippet: An ever-growing field faces longer, more intensive scrutiny.
articles.abstract: An ever-growing field faces longer, more intensive scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 — Two years before the next president is inaugurated and a full year before the first vote is cast, the contest for the White House is off to a breathtakingly fast start, exposing an ever-growing field of candidates to longer, more intensive scrutiny and increasing the amount of money they need to remain viable.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: In Raw World of Sex Movies, High Definition Could Be a View Too Real
articles.snippet: Pornographic movie studios have found that the high-definition format is accentuating physical imperfections in actors.
articles.abstract: Pornographic movie studios have found that the high-definition format is accentuating physical imperfections in actors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21 — The XXX industry has gotten too graphic, even for its own tastes.

articles.headline: Cracking Down on Mixtape CDs
articles.snippet: A recent crackdown on rap music mixtapes highlights the recording industry’s awkward relationship with what has long been an integral element of rap culture.
articles.abstract: A recent crackdown on rap music mixtapes highlights the recording industry’s awkward relationship with what has long been an integral element of rap culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long before Christmas, Jeff Baker, the chief of police of Morrow, Ga., a small town just south of Atlanta, and one of his officers were walking through a local shopping mall when they happened to pass a kiosk hawking rap music CDs. One in particular caught their attention.

articles.headline: Gambling Subpoenas on Wall St.
articles.snippet: Four investment banks have been issued subpoenas in an investigation into the multibillion-dollar online gambling industry.
articles.abstract: Four investment banks have been issued subpoenas in an investigation into the multibillion-dollar online gambling industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has issued subpoenas to at least four Wall Street investment banks as part of a widening investigation into the multibillion-dollar online gambling industry, according to people briefed on the investigation.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: New Somali Government Faces the Age-Old Problem of Clans
articles.snippet: Clans have been the bedrock of Somali identity since the first bands of nomads fought over water holes.
articles.abstract: Clans have been the bedrock of Somali identity since the first bands of nomads fought over water holes.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 18 — Fifteen men and one woman sat on the floor of a sunlit room. It was hot. Many people were sweating. The elders of the Ayr clan had called a political meeting, and very quickly it was clear that their attitudes toward the nation’s newly empowered transitional government were unanimous — and bitter.
